page.title: 13THE VIADUCT
page.content: The railway viaduct upstream was built by George Hudson in 1849 as part of his Leeds to York direct line.This railway was never completed due to the fall of the railway king and the viaducts only traffic was to and from Ingleby mills from Tadcaster station.The mill tower dates from the 1870's .The viaduct is now owned by the town,it was purchased by the Town Council from British Rail in 1980 for the nominal sum of a hundred pounds. Work has been done to repair the parapet wall and to cut steps down to both banks of the river.It now provides a pleasant footpath link across the river. During the summer children who bathe in the river jump from the viaduct into the water below.
